title: Representing Matroids over the Reals is ∃ℝ-complete
abstract:
Abstract
A matroid M𝑀M is an ordered pair (E,ℐ)𝐸ℐ(E,\mathcal{I}), where E𝐸E is a finite set called the ground set and a collection ℐ⊂2Eℐsuperscript2𝐸\mathcal{I}\subset 2^{E} called the independent sets which satisfy the conditions:
(i) ∅∈ℐℐ\emptyset\in\mathcal{I}, (ii) I′⊂I∈ℐsuperscript𝐼′𝐼ℐI^{\prime}\subset I\in\mathcal{I} implies I′∈ℐsuperscript𝐼′ℐI^{\prime}\in\mathcal{I}, and (iii)
I1,I2∈ℐsubscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2ℐI_{1},I_{2}\in\mathcal{I} and |I1|<|I2|subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2|I_{1}|<|I_{2}| implies that there is an e∈I2𝑒subscript𝐼2e\in I_{2} such that I1∪{e}∈ℐsubscript𝐼1𝑒ℐI_{1}\cup\{e\}\in\mathcal{I}.
The rank 𝗋𝗄​(M)𝗋𝗄𝑀{\sf rk}(M) of a matroid M𝑀M is the maximum size of an independent set.
We say that a matroid M=(E,ℐ)𝑀𝐸ℐM=(E,\mathcal{I}) is representable over the reals if there is a map
φ:E→ℝ𝗋𝗄​(M):𝜑→𝐸superscriptℝ𝗋𝗄𝑀\varphi\colon E\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{{\sf rk}(M)} such that I∈ℐ𝐼ℐI\in\mathcal{I} if and only if
φ​(I)𝜑𝐼\varphi(I) forms a linearly independent set.
We study the problem of Matroid ℝℝ\mathbb{R}-Representability over the reals.
Given a matroid M𝑀M, we ask whether there is a set of points in the Euclidean space
representing M𝑀M.
We show that Matroid ℝℝ\mathbb{R}-Representability is ∃ℝℝ\exists\mathbb{R}-complete, already for matroids of rank 333.
The complexity class ∃ℝℝ\exists\mathbb{R} can be defined as the family of algorithmic problems
that is polynomial-time equivalent to determining if a multivariate polynomial
with integer coefficients has a real root.
Our methods are similar to previous methods from the literature.
Yet, the result itself was never pointed out and there is
no proof readily available in the language of computer science.
